abstract.text: An object that manages the data-reading tasks associated with loading scene contents from a file or data.

inlineContent.text: You can also use a scene source to examine the contents of a scene file or to selectively extract certain elements of a scene without keeping the entire scene and all the assets it contains.
SceneKit can read scene contents from a file in a supported format, or from an
object holding the contents of such a file. Supported formats include the following:

When you include a scene file in DAE or Alembic format in your Xcode project, Xcode automatically converts the file to SceneKit’s compressed scene format for use in the built app. The compressed file retains its original
class can also load SceneKit archive files, which you create in the Xcode scene editor or programmatically by using the
object and the scene graph it contains.
For best results, place scene files that ship in your app bundle in a folder with the

extension, and place image files referenced as textures from those scenes in an Asset Catalog. Xcode then optimizes the scene and texture resources for best performance on each target device, and prepares your texture resources for delivery features such as App Thinning and On-Demand Resources.

abstract.text: A static byte buffer that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An encoder that stores an object’s data to an archive referenced by keys.
Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
Error codes that identify errors found during a scene-file-format consistency check.

abstract.text: A container for the node hierarchy and global properties that together form a displayable 3D scene.
An object that manages the data-reading tasks associated with loading scene contents from a file or data.
Options for creating scene sources and loading the scenes they contain.
The data object from which the scene source loads scene content.
Loads and returns all objects in the scene source that pass the test in a given block.
Loads and returns a specific object in the scene source.
Loads and returns a specific object in the scene source.
Returns the identifiers for all objects in the scene source of the specified class.
Initializes a scene source for reading the scene graph contained in an
object.
Initializes a scene source for reading the scene graph from a specified file.
Returns metadata about the scene.
Instantiates a scene from the scene source with the specified options.
Loads the entire scene graph from the scene source and calls the specified block to provide progress information.
Creates a scene source that reads the scene graph contained in an
object.
Creates a scene source that reads the scene graph from a specified file.
The URL identifying the file from which the scene source was created.
The file contributors.
Constants identifying phases of SceneKit’s scene loading process, used in a
block.
The signature for the block that SceneKit calls periodically to report progress while loading a scene.
Learn about implicit animations, explicit animations, and actions, and when to choose each in your app.
Metadata identifying the user and authoring tool that created a scene file, used with the
key.
Keys identifying errors found during a scene-file-format consistency check.
The metadata properties associated with a scene file, used by the
method.
Metadata describing the unit of measurement used in a scene file, used with the
key.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.

value.text: A static byte buffer in memory.
